content:
Just update. All of the largest mail providers are changing to some form of oauth authentication and your Thunderbird just does not support those protocols as implemented now. There are, and will not be, instructions for version 60. It went out of support some 5 years ago.

Theme and font size changer is, as you are aware obsolete, and has been for years. You do not need it, you just want it. Thunderbird has all the scaling settings you need built in an has had variations available for some years now with regard to density and font size. Although I note in your image that all of the settings are set to default, including scaling, so it is doing nothing anyway.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
Matt. If the current verion of Thunderbird has all the font size changes NOW, that it did not have THEN, then great, I will upgrade, BUT don't tell me that "You do not need it, you just want it" and " it is doing nothing anyway".

This is just plain wrong and rude!

When I did my last upgrade, and I could not use the add-on, my font sizes went all wrong, and I could not change it back to any size I could read by any Thunderbird control, and I had to search how to put my version back to a previous version and re-install the add-on to get a screen that I could read. So I DID need it (even if most of controls are at default - without the add-on and the lastest version then, I could not read the fonts as they were too small).

I was not the only person to have this problem at the time, and solution (revert back to previos version) was posted on your own help forum.

I would appreciate if you would just answer questions as posed, and not add any of your own personal and rude comments.

Yes, most set to default, but as I said, when I last upgraded TB, font size went to pot. Only way to get reasonable sizes fonts was to downgrade TB to what I had previously and re-load the add-on. It was probably the add-on that enabled me to get good size fonts, not TB. The fact that I have 'default' and that satisfies what I want is irrelevant. I checked this out now by removing the add-on, and fonts went bad again. Re-installed add on and all back to how I want it (even if that happens to be default). So that is why kept old version of TB and the add-on. Thus I need it (with my old version of TB).

Now, If you say that TB has sorted out all it's font size problems that it had many years ago, necessitating someone creating an add on to solve the problems, I will give it a try..... but be prepared to get another message if it does not get me back to how it is at present.

content: I recommend NOT attempting to add to GMAIL, but to make to local folders. To do that - click tools>addons and add the importexporttools addon - The folders to move are in the POP account listing - position cursor over Local Folders - highlight each individually, rightclick and select the importexport menu to import mbox file - when done, all the message folders should be in Local Folders, and the POP account may now be deleted. - -

creator: office810

content: The error also mentions 'relay.' Click 'account settings' and on the account page, look at bottom row where it identifies the SMTP server. Is it showing that email address? The concern is that you have multiple addresses and each one must use its own SMTP server. Check to be sure that this account is using that SMTP server. Since the SMTP server description field has the email address, it should appear in that row of the account page. Otherwise, check with email provider to verify what specific authentication is required.
creator: davidsk

content: The font needs to be installed into the operating system, not Thunderbird. Reminder: If used with HTML messages, your recipients will see your mail in their own font if they do not have that font installed. If your intent is for your own viewing, then set the font in Settings>General, and leave settings>composition font to 'variable width.' That ensures that recipients see messages in their chosen font, not yours.
creator: davidsk

content:
It is my understanding that Thunderbird shows the percentage bar at the bottom right corner when you're using 75% of your storage quota.

To show the bar all time open the config editor and set the pref "mail.quota.mainwindow_threshold.show" (without the quotes) to a value of "0" (without the quotes). https://support.mozilla.org/kb/config-editor
creator: christ1

content: Thanks, that did the trick exactly! And yes, it showed the default setting as 75.

content: It depends on what was done. Thunderbird does not maintain backups. If a POP account or Local Folders were deleted or tampered with, there may be no recovery. If a new profile was created, you might see if there is a prior folder in the ...appdata\roaming\thundrbird\profiles folder.
creator: davidsk

content:
Thanks a lot David. I successfully reached the appdata/roaming/thunderbird/profiles and got the followings :

- j7wxxxxx.default-release date modified 6/28/2024 - u29xxxxx.default date modified 1/16/2024

Can you help to understand this? And what shall I do afterwards.

Thanks a lot, Bambang
creator: bambangws

content: These are two profiles. Check in each one and click the Mail folder to see if a POP account is there If it is, click the account folder and see if there are any message files, such as inbox, sent, etc. there may be other entries such as inbox.msf, sent.msf, etc. Those would be messages - the msf files are just indexes and would be rebuilt if needed. Check also the Mail\Local Folders folder for any local message files. If found the files can be copied to the Mail\Local Folders folder of the active profile - which is probably the one with the newest date.
creator: davidsk

content: I don't know why OAuth2 doesn't appear in the drop-down, as it does in my setup. Open Config. editor from Settings/General and type mail.smtpserver.smtp1.authMethod in the search box (or change 1 to 2 or 3 to correspond to the outlook account (mail.server.server1.name displays the hostname of server 1). Edit mail.smtpserver.smtp1.authMethod and change the value to 10, then see if OAuth2 appears in the Account Settings.
creator: sfhowes

sfhowes - Changing "mail.smtpserver.smtp1.authMethod and change the value to 10" fixed it.

content: If the file is of the form file.mbox, remove the .mbox extension, then copy it into the Mail/Local Folders location of the profile, with TB closed. Help/More Troubleshooting, Profile Folder, Open Folder, to open the profile in File Explorer. Restart TB and view the folder under Local Folders in the Folder Pane.
creator: sfhowes

content: Close TB and delete TB Email Folder 1.msf, then restart TB and see if the mail in TB Email Folder 1 appears under the POP account.
creator: sfhowes

content: Okay, don't give up yet. Sometimes a new profile is created, keeping the prior profile. My first suggestion is to see if there are prior profiles. Try this: - click help>troubleshootinginformation - scroll down to 'profile folder' in left sidebar and click 'open folder' - you are now in the profile, back up one folder so that you are in the Profiles folder. - that may show multiple profiles. Only the one you are using is active; the others are dead weight - click to each of them. For POP account info, try the Mail folder to see if your account is there, and look in Mail\Local Folders to check for an local folders - check in each profile. If you find some account info that appears recent, post a screenshot of the message folders and we can assist in recovering them. thanks.
creator: davidsk

content: I got the problem figured out. Within my profile folder there was a file called prefs.js and also a lot of other similar files with a preceding number such as 43.prefs.js, which I assumed were backups. I opened the prefs.js and compared it with the most recent backup and found that the backup had all kinds of information that pointed to my missing accounts. I just renamed the prefs.js to something else, then renamed the most recent backup to prefs.js, reopened Thunderbird and everything was back to normal.
creator: sbbolson
